fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When the task-panel is expanded too much under issue search -> select detail view, the linked issues are no longer seen and not clickable. The issue is reproducible in Chrome, Firefox
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Go to issue search (select any criteria like My open issues), select the detail view from the right top side.
 # Drag the task panel as shown in the attached screenshot and screen recorder video. [^Screen Recording 2020-02-20 at 7.01.18 PM.mov]

h3. Expected Results

Linked issues should be visible and clickable
h3. Actual Results

The linked issues are no longer seen and not clickable.

And also, task panel selection is stored and restored the next time the window is refreshed
h3. Workaround

Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: When the task-panel is expanded too much under issue search- selecting detail view, the linked issues are no longer seen and not clickable.

fields.description:
h3. Summary

1) When moving an issue between projects or bulk moving multiples issues, we can observe that the query below consumes much of the active connection pool and db cpu.
 * Report from DB:
{quote}"SELECT OLD_ISSUE_KEY FROM moved_issue_key WHERE ISSUE_ID=:1 ORDER BY ID"
{quote}
||Id||Operation||Name||Rows||Bytes||Cost (%CPU)||Time||
|0|SELECT STATEMENT| | | |84 (100)| |
|1|SORT ORDER BY| |1|21|84 (3)|00:00:01|
|2|TABLE ACCESS FULL|MOVED_ISSUE_KEY|1|21|83 (2)|00:00:01|

 * (!) Query is doing full table scans 
 * {{moved_issue_key}} table structure:
{noformat}
           Table "public.moved_issue_key"
    Column     |          Type          | Modifiers
---------------+------------------------+-----------
 id            | numeric(18,0)          | not null
 old_issue_key | character varying(255) |
 issue_id      | numeric(18,0)          |
Indexes:
    "pk_moved_issue_key" PRIMARY KEY, btree (id)
    "idx_old_issue_key" UNIQUE, btree (old_issue_key)
{noformat}

2) Customers facing issue [JSWSERVER-20612 Dev.Status can get stuck paging over issue updates from Bitbucket Server, Bamboo or Fecru and cause excessive load on database|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSWSERVER-20612] can minimize the DB impact by adding this index:
{code:java}
CREATE INDEX idx_issue_id ON moved_issue_key (issue_id);{code}
h3. Suggested Solution

Add an index on the *issue_id* column for the table {{moved_issue_key}}

h3. Workaround
Add index manually
{noformat}
CREATE INDEX CONCURRENTLY idx_issue_id ON moved_issue_key (issue_id);
{noformat}
fields.summary: As a Jira Admin, I would like to add an index by ISSUE_ID column on the table moved_issue_key

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When using the permission helper, user in "Assignable User" permission is shown as "User does not have the 'Assignable User' permission" because the user is not in the issue security level, even though the user can be assigned to the issue.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a user with no admin permission.
 # Create an issue security schema with a security level that doesn't include the user.
 !Defined_Secuity_Level.png|width=270,height=138!
 # Associate the issue security scheme with the project.
 !Associate_Security_Scheme_with_Project.png|width=268,height=143!
 # Grant the user with the "Assignable User" permission under _Project Settings>Permission_.
 !Assignable_User_Permission.png|width=269,height=145!
 # Create an issue under the project in question and set the issue security level to the one created in 1.
 !Set_Security_Level_In_Issue.png|width=236,height=127!
 # Assign the issue to the user. The issue will be assigned.
 !Assign_Issue_To_User.png|width=233,height=125!
 # Check the permission helper for this user/issue/Assignable user permission.

h3. Expected Results

The Permission helper should return that the user is assignable to the issue because they have the "Assignable User" permission.
h3. Actual Results

The Permission helper returns that the user does not have the 'Assignable User' permission because they are not part of the issue security level.
 !Permission_Helper_result.png|width=259,height=139!
h3. Workaround

You may ignore the permission helper for this case.
fields.summary: Permission Helper shows incorrect results for "Assignable User" permission

fields.description:
Our customers are looking for the ability to clone an issue that has an epic link and have the new clone issue to retain the epic link from the cloned issue.

They want this feature to be accessible to all users that have the "read" access, however without giving users "edit issues" permissions to be able to clone the epic link.

 

Per our documentation at [Managing epics in a Scrum project|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRASOFTWARESERVER086/Managing+epics+in+a+Scrum+project], the 'Edit Issues' permission is required to add an issue to an epic. 
 The ideal would be to have the ability to select if the users might or might not copy also the Epic link (specific permission for it), without being related to the “edit issues” permission.

 

*Steps to reproduce:*
 1. Using an user account with permission to “Edit Issues”:
*  Create an Epic “Epic1”;
*  Create Story “Story1” and link to the Epic “Epic1”
*  Clone “Story1” as “Clone - Story1”
*  Observe that “Clone - Story1” was created and the link to “Epic1” was preserved.

 2. Using a user account without permission to “Edit issues”:
* Clone “Story1” as “Clone2 - Story1”
* Observe that “Clone2 - Story1” was created but +without the Epic link.+
fields.summary: As a user, I would like to be able to clone an issue and retain the epic link, even without permission to edit issue.

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

When issues are created on Jira, users will receive a "Issue [issue key] has been successfully created" message if the issue is created successfully. However, this message cannot be configured through the UI at the moment, and the time the message will be displayed cannot be configured as well.

h3. Suggested Solution

Allow users to configure what is displayed to users through the UI, along with the time the message will be displayed.
fields.summary: Allow users to configure the "Issue [issue key] has been successfully created" message

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Derived from previous JRASERVER-34423 - There are times when a Jira admin might need to create a large number of issues and choose to use the REST API as a means to do this. However you don't always want to send out notifications to all the users in the notification scheme when this takes place. It would be very helpful if the issue create endpoint api/2/issue had a means to do this, much like the edit issue endpoint (api/2/issue/\{issueIdOrKey} endpoint) has the notifyUsers query parameter.
h3. Suggested Solution

Implement the notifyUsers query parameter on the issue create endpoint as well.
h3. Why this is important

End users are easily annoyed by bulk issue creation. Many users have complained about Jira being overly chatty when it comes to email. This suggested solution would provide Jira admins a quick means to create issues without flooding the inbox of everyone on your team. This implementation method would still log issue histories and trigger other events/listeners just like notifyUsers currently works on api/2/issue/\{issueIdOrKey} endpoint.   The workaround can provide a solution, but it's not ideal because it is not granular enough to only limit notifications for this REST API call, it's overkill to completely change the notification scheme for this single issue creation event, and likely to leave the admin to forget to change it back.
h3. Workaround

It is possible for Jira admin to temporarily modify the notification scheme in use for that project so that no users are sent out notifications for such events as Issue Created, issue assigned, etc. However this work-around is not ideal as it prevents all such notifications for any project using that scheme.
fields.summary: REST API issue create endpoint should have the ability to suppress notifications

fields.description:
h3. Summary

A mechanism that cleans-up stale cluster tasks (JRASERVER-70585) contains a bug, where it takes a property set in minutes and passes it to a method expecting milliseconds, without converting between units.

As a result, a task can be cleaned up _way faster_ than it should.

Besides not being able to check the task's progress in the UI, errors like below might appear in the logs:
{code:java}
JiraTaskExecutionThread-2 ERROR /secure/admin/IndexReIndex!reindex.jspa [c.a.j.util.index.CompositeIndexLifecycleManager] Reindex All FAILED.  Indexer: SharedEntityIndexManager: paths: []
java.lang.RuntimeException: java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException: java.lang.NullPointerException
        at com.atlassian.jira.task.TaskManagerImpl.withTaskMap(TaskManagerImpl.java:132)
        at com.atlassian.jira.task.TaskManagerImpl.refreshTaskInTaskCache(TaskManagerImpl.java:573)
        at com.atlassian.jira.task.TaskManagerImpl.onProgressMade(TaskManagerImpl.java:481)
        at com.atlassian.jira.task.TaskProgressAdapter.makeProgress(TaskProgressAdapter.java:44)
        at com.atlassian.jira.task.context.TaskProgressPercentageContextSink.updateProgress(TaskProgressPercentageContextSink.java:41)
        at com.atlassian.jira.task.context.CompositeSink.updateProgress(CompositeSink.java:36)
        at com.atlassian.jira.task.context.PercentageContext$Progress.update(PercentageContext.java:64)
        at com.atlassian.jira.task.context.PercentageContext.setName(PercentageContext.java:34)
        at com.atlassian.jira.sharing.index.DefaultSharedEntityIndexManager.reIndex(DefaultSharedEntityIndexManager.java:118)
        at com.atlassian.jira.sharing.index.DefaultSharedEntityIndexManager.reIndexAll(DefaultSharedEntityIndexManager.java:93)
        at com.atlassian.jira.util.index.CompositeIndexLifecycleManager.reIndexAll(CompositeIndexLifecycleManager.java:66)
        at com.atlassian.jira.util.index.CompositeIndexLifecycleManager.reIndexAll(CompositeIndexLifecycleManager.java:49)
        at com.atlassian.jira.web.action.admin.index.ReIndexAsyncIndexerCommand.doReindex(ReIndexAsyncIndexerCommand.java:27)
        at com.atlassian.jira.web.action.admin.index.AbstractAsyncIndexerCommand.call(AbstractAsyncIndexerCommand.java:63)
        at com.atlassian.jira.web.action.admin.index.ReIndexAsyncIndexerCommand.call(ReIndexAsyncIndexerCommand.java:18)
        at com.atlassian.jira.web.action.admin.index.AbstractAsyncIndexerCommand.call(AbstractAsyncIndexerCommand.java:26)
        at com.atlassian.jira.task.TaskManagerImpl$TaskCallableDecorator.call(TaskManagerImpl.java:533)
        at com.atlassian.jira.task.TaskManagerImpl$TaskCallableDecorator.call(TaskManagerImpl.java:491)
        at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run(FutureTask.java:266)
        at java.util.concurrent.Executors$RunnableAdapter.call(Executors.java:511)
        at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run(FutureTask.java:266)
        at com.atlassian.jira.task.ForkedThreadExecutor$ForkedRunnableDecorator.run(ForkedThreadExecutor.java:216)
        at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)
Caused by: java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException: java.lang.NullPointerException
        at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.report(FutureTask.java:122)
        at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.get(FutureTask.java:192)
        at com.atlassian.jira.task.TaskManagerImpl.withTaskMap(TaskManagerImpl.java:130)
        ... 22 more
Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException
        at com.atlassian.jira.task.TaskManagerImpl.lambda$withTaskMap$1(TaskManagerImpl.java:128)
        at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run(FutureTask.java:266)
        at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1142)
        at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:617)
        ... 1 more {code}
In the scenario above, the re-index is happening as it should and the errors concern only reporting the progress.
h3. Environment
 * Jira DC with 2+ nodes, running Jira 8.7.1 (the _only_ affected Jira version)

(i) Note: Neither Jira 8.5.4 nor 8.8.0 are affected by this bug.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Perform a change that causes "Bulk Operation" action or start a re-index
 # Create a short database connection failure
 # The task with the job will be cleaned-up.
 (i) The task will still be executing. However, it will not be possible to check its progress and _NullPointerExceptions_ can appear in the logs.

h3. Actual Results

The property _is not_ converted from minutes to milliseconds.
h3. Expected Results

The property _is_ converted from minutes to milliseconds.
h3. Workaround

Either one of these:
 # Disable the feature by setting the "jira.dc.cleanup.cluser.tasks.disabled" feature flag and *restart the node*. You can [follow our documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jirakb/enable-dark-feature-in-jira-959286331.html] to learn how to set it.
 # Set the _cluster.task.cleanup.offline.node.threshold_ property to a high value, e.g. 1800000 (which equals to 30 minutes).
 ** *Remember to remove this override before upgrading Jira*, or else the mechanism will only clean-up tasks from nodes that are offline for ~3.5 years.
 # Upgrade Jira to a version containing a fix once it's available, i.e. 8.7.2, 8.8.0, or higher.

(i) Please note that *the workaround needs to be applied to every node in the cluster*, because the tasks are being removed by other nodes, not the node that's executing the task.

To make sure that the first workaround works, you can enable DEBUG logs for _com.atlassian.jira.cluster.ClusterTaskCleanupService_.
 During the service startup (when the node starts or after a plugin system restart) you should see the _"ClusterTaskCleanupService is disabled"_ message logged, instead of the _"Registering ClusterTaskCleanupService"_ message if the feature flag is still enabled.
fields.summary: Tasks can be cleaned too early in Jira DC 8.7.1

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
When exporting Number Custom Field values that are long, it would lead to some inconsistencies based on the file type exported. Below is the observed results:
(i) In this example, the value is *100,000,000,000,000*
|| | Exported as | Opened as | Rendered ||
|| | CSV | text file | 1.0E14 ||
|| | CSV | excel file | 100,000,000,000,000 ||
|| | XML | xml | 1.0E14 ||
|| | HTML | text file | 100,000,000,000,000 ||
|| | HTML | web page | 100,000,000,000,000 ||

In the Database, the value can be seen stored as *100,000,000,000,000* (Float Type). It is an intentional design choice that the value is stored as Float Type. Due to this, the value could be exported as the Exponent Form: *1.0E14*. However, the exported value should be consistent in all exported file types, either exporting as the Integer form or Exponent form.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a Number Custom Field
# Add the field into a Screen
# Add  long numeric value into the field (e.g.: 100,000,000,000,000)
# The value can be seen as different formats:
| UI | 100,000,000,000,000 |
| Database | 100,000,000,000,000 (Float) |
| CSV (opened as text file) | 1.0E14 |
| CSV (opened as excel file) | 100,000,000,000,000 |
| XML | 1.0E14 |
| HTML (opened as text file) | 100,000,000,000,000 |
| HTML (opened as web page) | 100,000,000,000,000 |

h3. Expected Results
All exported file types should have consistent formats

h3. Actual Results
The exported file types have inconsistent formats

h3. Workaround
To avoid this, the long numeric values can be stored in Text Custom Field rather than the Number Custom Field. However, this would allow alpha-numeric value input.
fields.summary: Export values are not consistent across different exported file type (csv, xml, html)

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Double scroll bars in Watchers list when 8 or more watchers are added. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a project with issues
 # Browse an issue 
 # Add 8 watchers to the issue

Issue is not reproducible in Jira 8.5.0/8.5.1.
Issue is reproducible with Jira 8.5.2 and above.

h3. Expected Results
One scroll bar per list

h3. Actual Results
Double scroll bars within the watchers list
 !Watchers.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround

* End user configurations:
** In MacOS, switch the 'Show scroll bars' settings (System Preferences >> General) to 'When scrolling':
 !MacOS.png|thumbnail! 
** In Windows 10, switch the 'Automatically hide scroll bars in Windows' settings (Settings >> Easy of Access >> Display) to ON:
 !Windows10.png|thumbnail! 

OR

* Jira system configurations:
Include the following in Announcement Banner (Jira Administration >> System):
{code:html}
<style>
#inline-dialog-watchers .recipients {
	max-height: none;
}
</style>
{code}
fields.summary: Double scroll bars in Watchers list

fields.description:
h3. Summary

If we have a default resolution set in Jira, creating issues through Portfolio plans results in the new issues having a Resolution Date, though no Resolution.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a project
# Create a Portfolio plan and add the project as an issue source
# Go to Resolutions page in JIRA (type g+g >> resolutions, under https://instance.atlassian.net/secure/admin/ViewResolutions.jspa)
# Select a resolution as default
# Add an issue to the plan via Portfolio
# Commit it so that it's created in JIRA

h3. Expected Results
The ticket is created without Resolution Date, as it doesn't have a resolution.

h3. Actual Results
It's created with no Resolution (as expected), but with a Resolution Date (not expected):
!resolution_problem.png|thumbnail!


h3.Workaround

h4. Workaround 1
# Unset default resolution (in 'Clear defaults') in Resolutions page
# Commit
# Set the default resolution back

h4. Workaround 2 (suggested in comments below)
# Change the 'Create' transition for this issue
# Add a post-function to clear the 'resolution' (not resolution date)
#* This should also clean the resolution date
fields.summary: Default Resolution causes issues to be created with Resolution Date and empty Resolution

fields.description:
Currently, if the default priority in the priority scheme is not set (or set to 'none'), JSD Portal will not display 'none' to users as a priority when creating an issue. Instead, JSD will pick up the priority that resides in the middle of the priorities in the priority scheme for that issue type.
For example, if the middle priority is 'medium'  but the default is 'none', JSD will show 'medium' priority as the default priority when creating the request.

This creates confusion as some customers expect that 'none' priority should exist in the list and either should not allow the users to create an issue at all until the correct priority is set, or create the issue with 'none' priority so that the priority can be set later

h5. Workaround

# Chose valid default priority in the default priority scheme (i.e. not 'none')
# Create "No priority' priority and set it to default
fields.summary: Better handle 'none' option in the list of priorities when creating issues via the portal

fields.description:
h4. Context
During a critical situation where Jira is unresponsive or extremely slow, it becomes very important to capture thread dumps *during the impacted period* to investigate potential causes.

Many admins may not be familiar with this and restart the server before proper data is collected, losing critical information.  This means that they will have to wait for another incident to occur before they can then collect proper information.

h4. Current Behaviour
Currently, Tomcat will generate a single thread dump in the event where the shutdown process has trouble closing threads in a timely manner.

h4. Suggestion
By default *every* shutdown should generate 3 thread dumps, 5 seconds between.  To extend this it can also have an easy method to disable this behaviour.
fields.summary: Configure Jira to always generate Thread Dumps on Shutdown

fields.description:
Customer's Security team scans has noticed that Atlassian Jira does not restrict of version of Flash player being used by the user. They highlighted the following.

<embed src="'+a.options.moviePath+k(a.options.moviePath,a.options)+'" loop="false" menu="false" quality="best" bgcolor="#ffffff" width="100%" height="100%" name="global-zeroclipboardflash-bridge" allowScriptAccess="always" allowFullScreen="false" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" wmode="transparent" pluginspage="http://www.macromedia.com/go/getflashplayer" flashvars="'+e+'" scale="exactfit">
codebase="http://fpdownload.adobe.com/pub/shockwave/cabs/flash/swflash.cab#version=9,0,124,0

The security team hopes that Atlassian can remediate this by:
Adding the attribute such as
codebase="http://fpdownload.adobe.com/pub/shockwave/cabs/flash/swflash.cab#version=9,0,124,0" to the object tag in html will communicate to the users flash player that version 9.0.124.0 is required to run this flash object.

If the user's Flash Player is prior to that version, the user will be warned and a dialog will prompt him to visit Adobe's Flash Player page and update to the latest version.
fields.summary: Jira: Restrict the version of Flash player being used by the user.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
All nodes in a Jira Data Center cluster will become inaccessible if there are rows in nodeassocation that refer to a project ID that does not exist in the project table ( aka project schemes for a project that does not exist ). 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Not reliably reproducible, we only have reports of this occurring after the fact. 
# However, you can create a row manually in nodeassociation using a project id value that doesn't exist in the project table to trigger this behavior

h3. Expected Results
If this occurs, for whatever reason, Jira at least remains accessible

h3. Actual Results
Jira becomes inaccessible, throwing 500 errors in the user interface until the rows are removed and every node is restarted

The below exception is thrown in the atlassian-jira.log file:
{noformat}
2020-02-03 17:51:15,860 http-nio-8080-exec-9 url:/jira/ url:/jira/secure/MyJiraHome.jspa url:/jira/secure/
Dashboard.jspa ERROR      [o.a.c.c.C.[.[.[/jira].[jsp.default_jsp]] Servlet.service() for servlet [jsp.default_jsp] in context with path [/jira] threw exception

fields.description:
The mobile app doesn't display the card as yellow or add a flag to the card. Unless a comment was added with the flag you cannot see which issues are flagged, and even so that requires clicking through the card.

 

I'm trying to convince my teams to stop using a "Blocked" status and to use the flagging functionality instead. This is going to hurt my case.
fields.summary: Mobile app does not indicate flagged issues

fields.description:
Summary: Ability to change the number of fields displayed when searching and sorting
h3. Problem

When a user performs a search, only 10 fields are displayed by default. The rest of the fields are hidden and often missed by newer users.  New users are often unaware of the additional fields that aren't displayed by default. 
h3. Suggested Solution

Add an option to change the number of fields displayed on search and sorting results.
h3. Why This Is Important

Newer users often miss important fields and aren't aware that they exist. The option to increase the number of fields displayed would increase the awareness for new users. It would decrease the learning curve for those newer to Jira. 
h3. Workaround

N/A
fields.summary: Search: Allow the amount of Fields Displayed to be modified

fields.description:
As a Jira admin, I'd like to be able to integrate Jira with Google Docs.
For example: I want to export issues, reports and filters to Google Docs natively from Jira.
fields.summary: As a Jira admin, I'd like to be able to integrate Jira with Google Docs

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When creating a branch from an issue in Jira on bitbucket the issue ID must be referenced automatically in Smart commits

# Link Jira with bitbucket and enable smart commits
# Create a branch from the issue 
# In the description you need to add the Issue id manually 

Customer wants the issue id to be added automatically when creating Smart commits.
h3. Suggested Solution
NA 
h3. Workaround 
(Optional)
fields.summary: Smart commits must add issue ids automatically

fields.description:
h3. Problem:

Jira 8.6 introduced [a new functionality|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jirasoftware/jira-software-8-6-x-release-notes-978220007.html#JiraSoftware8.6.xreleasenotes-check] that allows the users to migrate the existing customizations from their server.xml and setenv.sh when upgrading Jira.

The server.xml allows the users to keep their SSL configuration(among other configurations), however by not keeping the cacerts information, all SSL connections like LDAPS, POP3S, IMAPS will be broken after the upgrade. Besides the external SSL connections, the Jira users will also experience failures in the Gadget Feed Health Check due to the loss of the trusted certificates.
h3. Resolution and Impact:

By also maintaining the cacerts file after the upgrade, we will be able to provide a more seamless experience to our customers when upgrading Jira.
fields.summary: Maintain the bundled cacerts file when upgrading Jira

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently, there is no pattern or naming convention for the usernames created in Jira.
h3. Suggested Solution

Provide the ability for username convention in Jira limiting with a character or create automatically with Firstname and Lastname.
 Example:
 Firstname: Victor
 Last name: AllanSmith
 Jira Username: Victor.Allan (or) Victor.AllanSmith
fields.summary: username convention or pattern in Jira

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Drag and drop image in Visual Mode in comment results in full image rather than thumbnail

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Switch the comment to Visual Mode
# Add some text on the comment
# Then underneath that text, Drag and Drop an image

h3. Expected Results

The image shows up as a thumbnail in the comment

h3. Actual Results

Image shows up as a full blow image

h3. Notes

Prior to Jira 8, when images are dragged and dropped onto the comment in Visual Mode, the image is added to the issue, however, is not added to the comment. Only when switched to Text mode will Jira also include this in the comment as thumbnail

h3. Workaround

Switch to Text mode and then drag and the image. This will make sure that the image is added as thumbnail.
fields.summary: Drag and drop image in Visual Mode in comment results in full image rather than thumbnail

fields.description:
Today IssuesInFeature cannot be brought into a dashboard as a hierarchy/nested view . It can only be seen in a single row which is not helpful for a PO to see which Stories are assigned to a sprint and which are not. Essentially feature management is difficult . The hierarchy view is avaialble in the View screen mode, but the Sprints associated with the Stories are not available in the listed View 

 

Feature request - 

1- Enable a hierarchy view or nested view of Stories in a feature via dashbaords

2- Enable Sprint value to be added to the Stories in the IssuesInfeature of the View screen mode.
fields.summary: Provide IssuesInfeature as a hierarchy/ nested view in dashboards

h3. Issue Summary
When using IME, custom field search is triggered before confirm the character

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Access _Jira Administration > Issue > Custom fields_
# In Japanease [IME|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input_method], type "kyoto" and after a little time try to select "京都" from the suggested list

h3. Expected Results
Search is not triggered until confirm the character

h3. Actual Results
Search is triggered before confirm the character

 !auto_submit.gif!

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: When using IME, custom field search is triggered before confirm the character

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
When using the Jira server mobile application (at least Android version), and then viewing an epic issue, you are unable to see any of the children issue in that epic.

If you were viewing that issue within the main Jira Software website, (and you have Jira software application access), you would expect to be able to see all the child issues of that epic.


h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Have a Jira Software server instance setup to use the server mobile app
# Create an epic with multiple issues in it
# View that issue in the Jira server mobile app


h3. Expected Results
You can see the epic children issues keys and summaries

h3. Actual Results
You can't see those


h3. Workaround
none
fields.summary: Viewing Epic type issues in the Jira server mobile app does not display the children issues in that epic

fields.description:
*Summary* 

Currently Jira does not allow archiving sub-task issue type independently. Archiving sub-task can only be done by archiving its parent task which will archive *ALL* associated sub-tasks. The behaviour also not consistent with delete operation whereas user can delete inidividual sub-task (without its parent). 

*Ask* 

Allow archiving individual sub-task without its parent.
fields.summary: Archiving sub-task issue type

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
In larger instances of the software, there may be dozens of mail handlers configured or there me so much mail load  that needs to be processed that it's possible for incoming mail to consume all four caesium threads causing other tasks such as notifications, DVCS syncs, etc to fail silently.
Ideally, we want to have a large number of caesium workes, see JRASERVER-65809.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # create a large instance 
 # configure dozens of mail handlers OR a few with a tremendous amount of load, in one instance there were 680+ new messages from one handler in a period of less than 24 hours

h3. Expected Results
JIRA gracefully handles all scheduled tasks and allows other tasks besides mail handlers to be processed
h3. Actual Results
incoming mail will hold all four threads until the queue is processed 

Thread dumps show all four caesium threads running with a similar stack trace: 
{code}at java.net.SocketInputStream.socketRead0(java.base@11.0.6/Native Method)
	at java.net.SocketInputStream.socketRead(java.base@11.0.6/SocketInputStream.java:115)
	at java.net.SocketInputStream.read(java.base@11.0.6/SocketInputStream.java:168)
	at java.net.SocketInputStream.read(java.base@11.0.6/SocketInputStream.java:140)
	at sun.security.ssl.SSLSocketInputRecord.read(java.base@11.0.6/SSLSocketInputRecord.java:448)
	at sun.security.ssl.SSLSocketInputRecord.bytesInCompletePacket(java.base@11.0.6/SSLSocketInputRecord.java:68)
	at sun.security.ssl.SSLSocketImpl.readApplicationRecord(java.base@11.0.6/SSLSocketImpl.java:1103)
	at sun.security.ssl.SSLSocketImpl$AppInputStream.read(java.base@11.0.6/SSLSocketImpl.java:823)
	- locked <0x000000095c6597b0> (a sun.security.ssl.SSLSocketImpl$AppInputStream)
	at com.sun.mail.util.TraceInputStream.read(TraceInputStream.java:126)
	at java.io.BufferedInputStream.fill(java.base@11.0.6/BufferedInputStream.java:252)
	at java.io.BufferedInputStream.read(java.base@11.0.6/BufferedInputStream.java:271)
	- locked <0x000000095c65a020> (a java.io.BufferedInputStream)
	at com.sun.mail.iap.ResponseInputStream.readResponse(ResponseInputStream.java:103)
	at com.sun.mail.iap.Response.<init>(Response.java:131)
	at com.sun.mail.imap.protocol.IMAPResponse.<init>(IMAPResponse.java:60)
	at com.sun.mail.imap.protocol.IMAPProtocol.readResponse(IMAPProtocol.java:407)
	at com.sun.mail.iap.Protocol.command(Protocol.java:355)
	- locked <0x000000095c65a170> (a com.sun.mail.imap.protocol.IMAPProtocol)
	at com.sun.mail.imap.protocol.IMAPProtocol.fetch(IMAPProtocol.java:2151)
	at com.sun.mail.imap.protocol.IMAPProtocol.fetch(IMAPProtocol.java:2143)
	at com.sun.mail.imap.IMAPMessage.loadEnvelope(IMAPMessage.java:1493)
	- locked <0x0000001287fc4830> (a java.lang.Object)
	- locked <0x0000001287fe5040> (a com.sun.mail.imap.IMAPMessage)
	at com.sun.mail.imap.IMAPMessage.getSubject(IMAPMessage.java:441)
	at com.atlassian.jira.service.services.mail.MailFetcherService$MessageProviderImpl.getAndProcessMail(MailFetcherService.java:260)
{code} 
(!) These may vary based on mailbox type but the threads are all running and checking mail. 

h3. Workaround

Until a fix is found, it may be best practice to stagger how often mail handlers are checking mail.
fields.summary: Incoming mail is consuming all caesium threads blocking other scheduled tasks from running

Expand [Audit Log|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver/auditing-in-jira-applications-938847740.html] to include all "create", "edit" and "view" actions performed by users on Jira Server. Everything that users created, edited or viewed should be logged for the auditing purposes.

For example, currently viewing or creating issues does not leave a trace in Audit Log.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Attempting to create application link from JIRA to another application will fail if that application runs over HTTPS with SSL certificate that uses Subject Alternative Name (SAN) different from DNS name, e.g. rfc822name. JIRA 7.13 to 8.5 uses Apache HttpClient 4.5.5, which is affected by [https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HTTPCLIENT-1906]



h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Configure JIRA and Confluence to run over HTTPS with SSL certificate using entry Subject Alternative Name: RFC822Name=SysIngSUN@example.com
 # Ensure Confluence's certificate is accepted by SSLPoke on Jira side
 # From JIRA, create an application link to Confluence

h3. Expected Results

The applinks creation is successful on both sides.
 JIRA is able to load gadgets
h3. Actual Results

The applinks fails on JIRA side.

The below exception is thrown in the xxxxxxx.log file:
{noformat}
javax.net.ssl.SSLPeerUnverifiedException: Certificate for <confluence.example.com> doesn't match any of the subject alternative names: [SysIngSUN@example.com]
{noformat}
h3. Workaround

Use certificate without SAN at all, or with correct DNS name entry.
fields.summary: JIRA applinks fail if SSL certificate uses Subject Alternative Name (SAN)

fields.description:
Currently Backlog view is the only way you can priorities sprint, in Active sprints it is not allowed to change the priority you cannot priorities stories hence moving up or bottom of the sprint is not allowed even the right click option to do so is not available.

The only way you can do this is by going to "Backlog" view which in turn messes up because it makes it difficult to check the status of active sprint if there are stories which are already in Released/Resolved status and you want to only check the once which are in Sprint Backlog and Developing you have to move the Released/Resolved stories to bottom of the sprint or Top to get less clutter and doing that the actual priority list in backlog gets messed up .

 Is it possible to drag and drop these lanes themselves?
fields.summary: Stories swimlanes should be allowed to priorities active sprint.

fields.description:

fields.summary: Ability to sort the sequence of events in Batched notifications

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Performing ZDU, customer have to click on Ignore warnings on each node before proceeding. 
Because of this users were not able to login for some time. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # ZDU for a datacenter

h3. Expected Results

No user intervention for a user action. Users should always be able to login. 
  
h3. Actual Results

Observed admin has to click on Ignore warnings for each node and users are not able to login for that time period. 
 !image-2020-02-11-18-14-37-494.png|thumbnail! 
 Referring to the page, section :_List of custom changes after upgrade_ shows this screen would appear
 [Jira Service Desk 4.3.x release notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/servicedesk/jira-service-desk-4-3-x-release-notes-972351728.html] 
 However, it is not expected to show this screen for each node and admin to click on Ignore warning button.
h3. Workaround

Click on each Ignore all button to move ahead with Jira.
fields.summary: Post upgrade screen appears multiple times during zero downtime upgrade

fields.description:

 Log's referral number: fd1d0dcc-c3ae-426f-8328-c8f3e8d9aa38

fields.description:
Currently, when commenting on an issue including a new attachment, the comment can be added when the attachments are still uploading. The comment is posted, but the uploading attachments are not. 

h3. Steps to reproduce

# Go to an issue
# Type out a comment
# Upload an attachment large enough to take at least 10 seconds
# Add the comment before the upload finishes
fields.summary: Prevent Jira from adding comments until attachments are fully uploaded

fields.description:
Description

Atlassian Stack is made up of multiple Atlassian products like JIRA, Confluence, Bitbucket, etc. Currently, if you are an Atlassian Stack License holder, it is not possible to download the source code of the individual products.
Note: Atlassian Stack is currently EOL and only products renewed before July 1st, 2019 would be active.

Possible Solutions
Give the option of source code downloads against each of the Atlassian stack products.

Workaround:

Support team can provide source code in the meantime.
fields.summary: Allowing Source code downloads for Atlassian Access

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Clearing default resolutions on View Resolution page leads to missing XSRF Security Token warning

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Log in to Jira and visit "Resolutions" page (<baseURL>/secure/admin/ViewResolutions.jspa)
 # Select "Clear defaults"

h3. Expected Results
The default resolutions are cleared.

h3. Actual Results
XSRF Security Token Missing page appears: 
 !image-2020-02-10-12-53-36-644.png|thumbnail! 

The below exception is thrown in the xxxxxxx.log file:
{noformat}
2020-02-10 11:53:04,988 http-nio-7138-exec-24 INFO admin 713x74x1 xgj6ul xxx.xx.xx.xx /secure/admin/MakeDefaultResolution.jspa [c.a.j.web.action.XsrfErrorAction] The security token is missing for 'admin'. The browser has provided ZERO parameters.  Probably BUG! User-Agent : 'Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_14_6) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/79.0.3945.130 Safari/537.36'{noformat}

h3. Workaround
The workaround is to:
# On Resolutions page, add a new "dummy" Resolution
# Make it default.
#* At this point, the old default gets "transferred" to the "dummy" entry
# Delete the dummy entry
# The default Resolution is no longer set.

h3. Notes 
* Bug tested and reproduced in Jira 7.13.8. and 8.3.2
* Not reproducible in Jira 7.13.5
fields.summary: Clearing default resolution on View Resolution page leads to missing XSRF Security Token warning

h3. Problem Definition
Archived issues are marked as read-only:
bq. Issues will be read-only and accessible only with a direct link, mentions in other issues or applications, or on the Archived issues page (Issues > Archived issues). You won't be able to modify them but for audit purposes you can view or, if you're a Jira system admin, export them to a CSV file. 
from [Archiving an issue|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver/archiving-an-issue-968669980.html] 

When a user attempts to delete an archived issue via REST, the action fails and an error is returned stating that the operation is not permitted.

The user would be able to delete the issue.

Possible implementation: 
from [focusedCommentId=2354315|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-70614?focusedCommentId=2354315&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-2354315]

fields.description:
h3. Description
There are cases where a sprint is closed by mistake, then it is reopened, adjusted, and closed again. The *COMPLETE_DATE* column of the *AO_60DB71_SPRINT* table is the information used at the Sprint Report (and others), and this information is always updated each time you close the sprint again.

Sometimes, though, the sprint is completed by mistake and the reports  should consider the correct complete date, but instead it considers the latest complete date which, on these cases, will be after the reopening.

The End Date is more accurate, but it wouldn't make sense as the complete date could be different than what is filled at the End Date. For example:

# Create Sprint A and set it's End Date as 02/05/2020
# Complete sprint at 03/05/2020. The Completed Date will be 03/05/2020
# Reopen the Sprint A at 04/05/2020 because there were some missing stories from another sprint that were done at Sprint A. Include these stories at the sprint, and complete it again. The Completed Date will be 04/05/2020.
# The Sprint Report will be generated considering the COMPLETE_DATE, which was at 04/05/2020, which is understandable, however, the correct close date was 03/05/2020. Neither END_DATE not COMPLETE_DATE stores this date for the sprint to work correctly.
 
h3. Current Workaround
It is needed database manipulation to change this information, which is not supported by Atlassian and could lead to further errors.

h3. Suggestion
A few suggestions:
- Have the Completed Date field at the Sprint Report to be editable so the user can input the date he wants, or
- Have the COMPLETE_DATE field editable when completing the sprint, or
- Have a third field like "ORIGINAL_CLOSED_DATE" which will always inform the date the sprint was first closed, by mistake or not.
fields.summary: Sprint reports should have an editable completed date

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Trying to configure a new application link or loading the Application link page to list the status of existing Applinks will show "NETWORK ERROR" in red.  
The REST client  {{atlassian-rest-module:3.2.16}} while reading headers (eg. Content-Type) does a _case-sensitive lookup_ for them (headers name should be _case-insensitive_). So when headers are in lower case it can't parse them properly. The problem is triggered by the proxy server, which is converting all HTTP header names to lower-case.

h3. Environment
* Use of proxy which converts the HTTP headers to lower-case. 
** Example HAProxy with native HTTP representation (HTX) enabled. This will force headers internally to be stored in lowercase.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Setup two Atlassian applications behind a proxy
# Setup HAProxy with HTX enabled on one of the application
# Configure Application link between the two applications

h3. Expected Results
The application link can be configured and established

h3. Actual Results
The application link is not configured correctly with "NETWORK ERROR" due to wrong headers.

h3. Diagnosis
Generate HAR file in the process of configuring or loading the Application link page. 
* On Application link page load, locate {{/rest/applinks-oauth/latest/applicationlink/<applinkid>/authentication}} and see *UNEXPECTED_RESPONSE* in its body.

h3. Notes
* As per [RFC 2616|https://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec4.html#sec4.2], HTTP 1.1 expects headers name to be case-insensitive. 
* HTTP 2.0 enforce the requirement for the headers to be all lowercase as per [RFC 7540 about HTTP/2|https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7540#section-8.1.2], see JRASERVER-70517

h3. Workaround
On the proxy side, disable the handling of headers to all lowercase:
* Example HAProxy, set {{no option http-use-htx}}
* Example for Envoy - [header_casing|https://www.envoyproxy.io/docs/envoy/latest/configuration/http/http_conn_man/header_casing]
fields.summary: Application Link Status page fails to load due to Case-sensitive checks for Headers

fields.description:
h3. Scenario:
 - Issue is created and customer has communication with Agent
 - During Email communication the reporter may forward the mail to another person that was not participant on the issue
 - This person now answers to this email with the correct issue ID in the subject and a new issue is created

In System Settings "Email requests - Public Email comments" the setting "Yes, allow non-customers and external people to comment on a request via email" is activated. All Service Desk users are internal and read from the Active Directory.

Considering the user has access to add comments in the issue, comments are still not added in the issue. To get it working here is the workaround:

Create an Organisation and add all the users to this group and also add the Organisation on the issue. 

However as it is necessary to put every customer into the same Organisation and add the Organisation to every issue. This would also mean that every customer would be able to read every issue. And this would be no solution due to privacy issues.
h3. Expected behaviour:

We need to find out some other solution to prevent the privacy issues.
fields.summary: Privacy issues when commenting in issue via email.

This feature is very important as Security is an important requirement in most organizations if not all.
fields.summary: Force existing users to comply with the new Password Policy

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
*NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-60081].
{panel}
h3. Summary

A user who is a member of the Project Role (Administrators) which has been added to the *Administer Project* permission is unable to edit the Project Lead/Default assignee, if this user is not grated the *Jira Administrators* global permission.

According to the [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jira/managing-project-permissions-185729636.html], the *Administer Project* permission allows any user w/ the permission to edit the Project Lead:
{quote}Permission to administer a project in JIRA. This includes the ability to edit project role membership, project components, project versions and some project details ('Project Name', 'URL', 'Project Lead', 'Project Description').
{quote}
However, with this bug, a user with the *Administer Project* permission is unable to edit the Project Lead. No errors appear in the UI or in the logs.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Log into Jira as a user who has *Jira Administrators* global permission
 # Go to the user management page, and create a user (referred to as "testuser")
 ## Grant this user Jira application access
 ## (!) Do not grant this user with the *Jira Administrators* global permission
 # Create a new project
 # Go to the page *Project settings > Users and Roles*
 # Grant the user "testuser" the project role *Administrators*
 # Click on the *Edit defaults* button and try to set any user as the project lead
 # Verify that this user is properly added to the "Project Lead" field
 !Step1.png|thumbnail!
 # Log into Jira the user "testuser" and navigate to *Project settings > Users and Roles*
 # Click on *Edit Defaults*
 # Change project lead to another user and click on *Update*
 !Step2.png|thumbnail!

h3. Expected Results

The update completes and pop-up window closes. User is able to update changes to Project Lead and you see the Project Lead correctly updated on the page:
!Step5.png|thumbnail!
h3. Actual Results

Instead, the following happens:
 - The project lead does not change and a blank picture is displayed next to it:
 !Step3.png|thumbnail!
 - When the page is refreshed, the lead project shows the original user:
 !Step4.png|thumbnail!

h3. Workaround

Grant the user who is unable to edit the project lead with the *Jira Administrators* global permission. If you grant the user user with this global permission, they will be able to edit the Project Lead.
 Or if that is not possible, another project administrator who has the *Jira Administrators* global permission can make the change.
fields.summary: Project administrator cannot edit Project Lead/Default assignee if they are not granted the Jira Admin global permission

fields.description:
Hi,

regarding our ticket GHS-175766 I would like to open a new feature request. We need be able to hide time tracking information from all other places than the worklog tab (as far as I know this is the issue history and all activity streams).

While we did discus, that it would be good that this information would only be displayed to certain groups, roles or  users with a specific permission, this request is for a new feature to be able to customize what contents are displayed in the history and activity streams.
The possibility to customize would not only prevent users to see this information but also it would prevent the history from getting overloaded with useless information such as several hundreds of created or edited worklogs.
fields.summary: Possibility to customize content appearing in Issue-History and Activity-Streams

fields.description:
Hello Product Team,

We are looking for two kinds of improvements in the Saved Filter's Permissions. 

h3. *Suggestion # 1*

- If there are a number of filters that require the same set of Edit & View permissions, there should be a way to share the permissions across multiple filters. 

For instance, if there are more than 10 saved filters with different JQL queries. All those 10 filters require the same set of view and edit permissions. We have to go to Each saved filter, click on Details, Edit permissions and then add Viewers and Editors. This gets tedious when the number of saved filters increases. There is, unfortunately, no provision to copy over these permissions to all these Filters which will save a lot of time. 

(!) Please note that Copy filters functionality does not Copy permissions. So we cannot use this option.


h3. *Suggestion # 2*
While adding the viewers or editors for a particular Issue filter, there should be a way to multi-select values in the projects category. If we are trying to select around 15 projects, each time we are made to select just one value. then click on add viewers and select another value. This is time-consuming and ineffective. In Enterprise set up, we have seen filters having more than 20 project viewers and adding so many viewers or editors to 20 such saved filters makes it even more difficult and time-consuming. 



Please feel free to comment or request more information.
fields.summary: Ability to Multi Select Projects while editing ISSUE FILTERS' Permissions or Ability to share same set of Permissions (View & Edit) across multiple Filters

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
When filtering archived issues by specific dates using the "From" and "To" filters, and inserting the exact period you want to bring issues, the last day is ignored and issues from it are not brought in the results.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Setup a clean Jira instance and create a sample project with a few issues
# Archive, let's say, 2 issues at February 3rd, for example.
# Go to the *Archived Issues* page and click *Search*. It will bring all 2 archived issues.
# Now, filter it *From: February 1st* and *To: February 3rd*.

h3. Expected Results
The above filter should bring the two issues archived at February 3rd.

h3. Actual Results
The filter doesn't bring any results.

h3. Workaround

If you change the filter to *To: February 4th*, the results will bring the issues from February 3rd. Basically, you always need to inform a day forward in the *To:* filter to bring issues from the date you want as the limit.
fields.summary: Filtering archived issues by dates return incorrect results

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Assume some node in JIRA Datacenter is executing long-running task with has cluster-wide status. If at some point progress abnormally stops before the job is complete, then job will be stuck for the whole cluster.
The stuck job is stored in an in-memory cache and is replicated to other nodes when they start. All nodes must be shut down at the same time in order for this job to be removed from cache.

h3. Suggested Solution
Implement the job which periodically cleanup tasks from the nodes that are offline for a long time.  
 
h3. Implemented Solution
A scheduled job described [in this comment|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-70585?focusedCommentId=2349285&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels%3Acomment-tabpanel#comment-2349285]

h3. Workaround 
See JRASERVER-66722
fields.summary: Periodically clean-up cluster tasks from offline nodes

fields.description:
Some long-running tasks submitted by users (e.g. re-indexing, user anonymization, bulk issue edit, etc.) can become stuck in Jira Data Center, when the node that was executing them crashes or is shut down.

Jira can clean up those (since https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-66204). However, only a log message is added when such task is cleaned.

It is very likely that the person that submitted the task does not have access to logs or simply does not (want to) monitor them all the time. *Jira should notify the user that submitted the task that is being cleaned up about doing so*, to allow them to react - e.g. by re-running the operation.

This could be an in-product flag message, an email or some other way.
fields.summary: When stuck operations are removed in DC, users should be notified

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Some actions in Jira are run in long transactions - e.g. issue create or issue status transition.

When some code requests a rollback, the whole action is reverted. If that code doesn't provide any logging, it's impossible to check _what code_ and _why_ requested the rollback.

h3. Suggested Solution
Jira should provide an optional, low-level log that would generate a stacktrace, allowing Jira admins and Atlassian Support Engineers to troubleshoot such issues.
fields.summary: Jira should have logging when transactions are rolled back

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

In previous versions, the Custom Field admin page (ViewCustomFields.jspa) displayed context restrictions by issuetype. This allowed customers to easily see which Issue Types the custom field was restricted to. As of 7.12, this information is no longer visible, and you must click into *Gear Icon* > *Configure* of the custom field to view the Issue Type restrictions. This makes it difficult to quickly access a custom field's restrictions. 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a new custom field (or use an existing one).
 # Click *Gear Icon* > *Configure*. 
 # Click the *Edit Configuration* link.
 # Select an issue type to restrict this custom field to. 
 # Click the *Modify* button.
 # Navigate back to ViewCustomFields.jspa. 
 # Note there are no Issue Type restrictions visible on the page. 

h3. Expected Results

Issue Type restrictions are visible on ViewCustomFields.jspa
h3. Actual Results

No restrictions are visible. See the following example: 

!image-2020-01-31-11-19-07-540.png|width=831,height=30!

Prior to 7.13, this information was available. See the following example: 

!image-2020-01-31-11-23-10-134.png|width=969,height=271!
h3. Workaround

 It is possible to revert back to the old view, [using a feature flag|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jirakb/enable-dark-feature-in-jira-959286331.html]: *jira.customfields.paginated.ui.disabled.* This will revert the entire UI back to the pre-7.13 view -  including the removal of the new filter options.
fields.summary: Context restriction by issuetype is no longer visible on the Custom Field admin page

fields.description:
h4. Problem Definition

The endpoint *rest/api/latest/customFields* only contains a count of the projects to which the CF is restricted, but not the list of the projects themselves. In addition, there is no information returned in the payload about issue type restrictions (types and number of Issue types that the CF is restricted to). This makes it more difficult and time consuming for administrators to determine context restrictions. 
{code:java}
  "id": "customfield_10200",
            "name": "payload check for rest api",
            "type": "Checkboxes",
            "searcherKey": "multiselectsearcher",
            "self": "http://<jiraserver>/rest/api/latest/customFields/customfield_10200",
            "numericId": 10200,
            "isLocked": false,
            "isManaged": false,
            "isAllProjects": false,
            "projectsCount": 1,
            "screensCount": 1  {code}
h4. Suggested Solution

Return all context restrictions in the rest/api/latest/customFields payload, including: # of Issue types, list of Issue Types and list of projects. 
h4. Work Around 

Currently you need to manually find this information in the UI by navigating to the Custom Field administration page, and clicking on the Gear icon and Configure to view the restrictions.
fields.summary: Add context restriction by issuetype and list of projects to the rest/api/latest/customFields endpoint

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When a Confluence page is linked onto a Jira issue, sometimes it would be helpful to be able to just hover over the link to that page to get a preview of what is on it, rather than needing to click that link and visit the other site to see content there. 

h3. Suggested Solution
It would be great if the application link integration could be improved in some manner to permit the sharing of such data here in a preview mode without having to click on the link to see the content


h3. Why this is important
Could offer end-users an improved performance experience, but not having to always wait for to see what's on a page by clicking on it.  Instead you can get a sense of what is there just by hovering there, and if you need to edit it, then you can visit the page.
fields.summary: When hovering on a link to a Confluence page, show a preview of that page

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Print Preview does not show all pages for attachments (PDF)
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Open an issue
 # Add a PDF attachment(which has more than 4 pages, attached sample for reference)
 # Click on the Attachment to view it
 # Right-click and click print
 # Print preview shows only two pages

fields.summary: Print Preview does not show all pages for attachments (PDF)

fields.description:
h3. Summary The *atlassian-bot-killer* plugin watches every request via a servlet Filter and checks if it has seen the session before. If not it must be the first request for that session. It then stores the original session timeout in the session itself and sets the session _inactivity timeout to be 1 minute_. If the session makes a second request then it gets bumped back to the original timeout of say 5 hours. It follows the same strategy on requests with a known user however to be conservative it sets the inactivity time out to be 10 minutes instead of 1. Context [getting-rid-of-unwanted-http-sessions|https://www.atlassian.com/blog/archives/getting-rid-of-unwanted-http-sessions] Due to wrong logic, all users are considered bots and all sessions have their inactive lifetime reduced, overwriting all normally configured settings. This limits user's session to one minute or one hour. h3. Steps to Reproduce Based on [~kczeladko] steps: # Configure session timeout to 300 = 5h in $JIRA_INSTALL/atlassian-jira/WEB-INF/web.xml # Restart Jira # Create page in $JIRA_INSTALL/atlassian-jira/secure/sessionattributes.jsp to check session attributes # Do a 1st visit to Jira http://company.xyz/jira/secure/sessionattributes.jsp # Visit 2nd time Jira - sessionattributes.jsp # Visit 3rd time Jira - sessionattributes.jsp h3. Expected Results User session timeout is 5h (300 min, 18000 sec). * 1st call {noformat} Session ID: 6CA579E3F814476B4FA00F1D9034BD49 Max Inactive Interval: 18000 {noformat} * 2nd call {noformat} Session ID: 6CA579E3F814476B4FA00F1D9034BD49 Max Inactive Interval: 600 com.atlassian.labs.botkiller.BotKiller: 18000 {noformat} * 3rd call {noformat} Session ID: 6CA579E3F814476B4FA00F1D9034BD49 Max Inactive Interval: 18000 com.atlassian.labs.botkiller.BotKiller: 18000 {noformat} * Note the change of "Max Inactive Interval": 18000 -> 600 -> 18000 h3. Actual Results * User session timeout is 1h * BotKiller take Max Inactive Interval value read session timeout from web.xml, but still overwrite MaxInactiveInterval to 3600 {noformat} Max Inactive Interval: 3600 ... com.atlassian.labs.botkiller.BotKiller: 18000 {noformat} * Change of "Max Inactive Interval": 18000 -> 60 -> 3600 h3. Notes * Based on comment from [~thomas.weissschuh893360640] [JRASERVER-60844?focusedCommentId=1598784|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-60844?focusedCommentId=1598784&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-1598784] {quote} In BotKiller.java the method isThereAUserInPlay is used to determine if a request is performed by an actual user instead of anonymously. For this it checks if the Jira usermanager is available to make sure this method will not fail during Jira startup or shutdown. To hook into the Jira lifecycle the BotKiller class implements to LifecycleAwareInterface and expects to be managed by the Jira component system to call its onStart method to enable its real functionality. Unfortunately the class is not actually registered as a component in Jira (as indicated by the plugin manager web UI) and instead is managed by the BotKillerFilter class. BotKillerFilter however does never call onStart, so that BotKiller never thinks that Jira has started and therefore classifies all requests as being from bots. {quote} * Related KB [When using a third-party authenticator, user sessions may terminate earlier than expected when idle|https://confluence.atlassian.com/kb/when-using-a-third-party-authenticator-user-sessions-may-terminate-earlier-than-expected-when-idle-933071468.html] * {{sessionattributes.jsp}} code: {code:Java|borderStyle=solid} <%@ page session="true" import="java.util.*" %>

Session attributes

<% Enumeration keys = session.getAttributeNames(); out.println("Session ID: " + session.getId() + "
"); out.println("Max Inactive Interval: " + session.getMaxInactiveInterval() + "
"); while (keys.hasMoreElements()) { String key = (String)keys.nextElement(); out.println(key + ": " + session.getValue(key) + ""); } %> {code} h3.Workaround * Disable BotKiller Plugin
fields.summary: Atlassian Bot Killer plugin reduces all users session timeout to one hour

fields.description:
As per [our release notes for Jira 8.6|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jirasoftware/jira-software-8-6-x-release-notes-978220007.html#JiraSoftware8.6.xreleasenotes-checkJiracopiesoverchangesfilesonupgrade], during upgrades Jira will show a page to the admins to ask them whether they want existing changes to config files migrated to the new version.

Some clients have configuration management tools in place to keep customisations in place and clicking "copy" would interfere with this process. Making this feature optional will prevent situations whereby instance users click on the "copy" button by mistake.

Currently there is no workaround or option to disable the feature.
fields.summary: Make tracking of config file changes optional

fields.description:
I'm using Kanban on a project with multiple deliverables. We don't use versions for anything. Our team's issues collected in the "done" column forever. The team thought this was weird, since if they're "done", why aren't they disappearing?

The kanban board sub-filter is the answer. The default behaviour for kanban is to show issues with no `fixVersion`. Since we don't use those, they'll collect there forever.

(Aside: what would it mean to "release" a project with no versions? Does that make sense?)

The other weird thing about the filter is its mental model. The correct model: things that match the query will be *visible* on the board; everything else will be *hidden* after a period of time. The problem with this, however, is the context in which the filter is changed. If you're like my team, you're going to change it when your "done" column gets heavy... which means you're going there to *hide* issues, not *show* them. As a result the query can seem a bit nonsensical at first -- I accidentally made everything show up as "done" the first time.

I think one of two things could be done here:

* the description of the kanban sub-filter could be updated to more clearly state that it makes issues visible, and anything that *doesn't* match it will get hidden.
* the field's purpose could be inverted; it would be about selecting issues that are "done". This shift can drastically simplify the mental model for end-users (no double-negatives to think about; you're selecting a discrete set intersection, rather than defining two sets and taking the difference).
fields.summary: The kanban board sub-filter experience could be better

fields.description: The JMX monitoring flag in Atlassian Jira Server and Data Center before version 8.6.0 allows remote attackers to turn the JMX monitoring flag off or on via a Cross-site request forgery (CSRF) vulnerability.
fields.summary: JMX monitoring flag in Jira was vulnerable to XSRF/CSRF - CVE-2019-20405

fields.description:
The API in Atlassian Jira Server and Data Center before version 8.6.0 allows authenticated remote attackers to determine project titles they do not have access to via an improper authorization vulnerability.

h3. Note on fix
* The fix was tested internally before backporting it and no issues were detected. (/) 
* However, the fix changes the behavior of the REST API, therefore as a stability precaution we introduced a feature flag that disables the fix. (i) In case of any problems with the new behavior enable the {{com.atlassian.jira.projectvalidate.anonymous}} feature flag ([feature flag documentation for reference|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jirakb/enable-dark-feature-in-jira-959286331.html]).
fields.summary: Improper authorization on project titles vulnerability in Jira - CVE-2019-20404

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Users would expect to get outcomes for Epics related to the Issue when using this JQL:
{code}
issue in linkedIssues("QQQ-1", "has Epic", "is Epic of")
{code}
(i) 'QQQ-1' is the Issue Key

However, when using the JQL, it would return no results nor error message:
 !JQL1.png|thumbnail! 

The expected behavior when using non-existing Link Types would be to receive an error message:
 !JQL2.png|thumbnail! 
This current behavior can be confusing

*Side note:* Creating a Link Type with "has Epic" and "is Epic of" would yield results should there be any issues using the Link Type. However, this can cause further confusion.

h3. Suggested Solution
Throw an error message when using the JQL to avoid confusing the user. Additionally, the error message could also include the alternative JQL to use.

h3. Workaround 
Use the following JQL based on the use case:
* If the Issue with an Epic is known:
{code}
Issue in (<key>)
{code}
(i) Replace <key> with the Issue Key linked to an Epic. If there are multiple Issue Keys, add it in with ','
** From the outcome, take note of the Epic Link column as that would indicate the name of the Epics
* If you want to display all Epics in a Project
{code}
project = <pkey> AND "Epic Name" is not EMPTY
{code}
(i) Replace <pkey> with the Project Key
** The outcome would display the Epics in the Project. Take note of the Epic Name column to know the Epic name and Key column to know the Issue Key for the Epic
* To list out all the Issues linked to a known Epic:
{code}
"Epic Link" = epic1
{code}
(i) epic1 is the Epic Name/Link
** The outcome would list out all the issues that have the 'Epic Link' field populated with the stated Epic Name/Link
fields.summary: Using 'has Epic' and 'is Epic of' with 'linkedIssues()' JQL should return error message

fields.description:
*Issue*: When customers are importing the data from CSV files, the due date on the issues is displayed as 1 days less than actual dates mentioned in CSV file. 

Currently this is due to the server timezone difference between server and client machines. As Jira converts the date/time to server timezone and saves the data, the same is displayed when users try to access imported issues.

*Impact*: When customers would like to merge projects or migrate data from different instances across different geographies, this results in data discrepancies.

*Example*: due date was "12/30/2019 00:00 +05:30" in .csv file, however, after import Jira shows as 29th Dec 2019while browsing through the issue. The server timezone is 10:30 hours behind as compared to client timezone in this case.

*Suggestions for Improvement*: Jira should retain the value of timestamps when using CSV imports or provide users with ability to select timezone for the import so that there data remains consistent.
fields.summary: Due date is shown 1 day less than actual date when importing issues from CSV files.

fields.description: The API in Atlassian Jira Server and Data Center before version 8.6.0 allows remote attackers to determine if a Jira project key exists or not via an information disclosure vulnerability.

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Accessing an issue collector form directly through the URL using the custom template shows a blank page.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create an issue collector using a *Custom* template.
 # add at least one Custom field to this issue collector (Description, Component, priority, attach file)
 # While editing the issue collector, get its ID in the URL.
 # Access the issue collector directly using the following URL:
{code:java}
https://<INSTANCENAME>.atlassian.net/rest/collectors/1.0/template/form/<ISSUE COLLECTOR ID>{code}
 # These steps are based in this article:

 - [How to Access Issue Collector Form without Embedding it in a Page|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jirakb/how-to-access-issue-collector-form-without-embedding-it-in-a-page-826872619.html?_ga=2.121503496.1894725997.1532366143-679363520.1532116124]

h3. Expected Results

Using a *Raise bug* or *Got feedback?* the form is correctly rendered:

!expected.png|thumbnail!
h3. Actual Results

The URL shows a blank page when using the *Custom* form:

!blank.png|thumbnail!

 
h3. Workaround

None.
fields.summary: Accessing an issue collector form directly through the URL shows a blank page

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

JVM Code Cache memory check is failing in ATST version 1.23.1 with JDK 11 (Open JDK or Oracle)
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Install Jira 8.5.3 with JDK 11
 # Start it
 # Upgrade Troubleshooting and Support Tools plugin to the latest (1.23.1) version
 # Clear catalina.out log file under *<JIRA_INSTALL>/logs* directory because the health check may be responding to outdated messages there
 # Navigate *Administration > System > Troubleshooting and Support Tools > Instance Health* to check the warnings

h3. Expected Results

It shouldn't show any warning messages for an empty instance because the default size of *ReserveCodeCacheSize* parameter is *512mb* which is quite sufficient.
h3. Actual Results

It shows a warning message like below:
 !Screenshot 2020-01-29 at 14.52.09.png!

h3. Note
Possibly related: change since Java 9 [JEP 197: Segmented Code Cache|https://openjdk.java.net/jeps/197] 
bq. Divide the code cache into distinct segments, each of which contains compiled code of a particular type, in order to improve performance and enable future extensions.

h3. Workaround

No action required. It's a false message. However, it still worths to search for *CodeCache is full. Compiler has been disabled* message in catalina.out file. If you see this message there;
 * Increase *ReserveCodeCacheSize* by following [Full Code Cache Size Causes Jira Server to Crash or Perform Slowly|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jirakb/full-codecache-causes-jira-server-to-crash-or-perform-slowly-314447083.html] article
 * Stop Jira
 * Remove catalina.out log file
 * Start Jira
 * Raise a ticket to Atlassian Support in case of the same warning message.
fields.summary: JVM Code Cache memory check is failing in ATST version 1.23.1 with JDK 11

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Jira REST endpoint responses contain 'setCookies' header. In case of using REST client that includes cookies in subsequent request by default, rate limiting will no longer apply to these requests because they will contain characteristics classifying them as originating from UI traffic.

The affected clients may include not only client applications like Postman but also rest client libraries for programming languages.
h3. Steps to Reproduce

Prerequisite: REST calls performed using Postman
 # Start Jira DC Node
 # Set rate limit to allow 1 request per 1 minute with burst size 1
 # Send a request to rest/api/2/myself with basic authentication
 # Observe that it's not rate limited but it response does contain rate limiting headers (X-RateLimit-Remaining - 0 being most significant)
 # Repeat the request from 3. within 60 seconds

h3. Expected Results

Request gets rate limited. Response headers contain correct information about rate limiting
h3. Actual Results

Request does not get rate limited and its response does not contain rate limiting information
h3. Workaround

Depending on the REST client app/library used, disabling cookie preservation for subsequent requests causes the requests be correctly rate limited.
fields.summary: Initial requests cause subsequent requests to be not rate limited for some REST client tools
